reviews.review_text: This is one of the most underplayed, disrespected games out there. Amazing gameplay, good campaign (Reasonably generic, but introduces you well to the concept of the game) and well... YOU SPAWN IN FROM ♥♥♥♥ING ORBIT. I've clocked everything on this game and I'm in the top one hundred in the world, but that not saying much because only about 26000 people sit on the leaderboard, and no one plays anymore. ♥♥♥♥ing great game... just wish people would play again to revive the multiplayer.

Love this game, For now the Multiplayer is dead, and this game is 99.9% based on multiplayer. the 0.01% is a story mode that basically serves as a long 'how to'. BUT your in luck the game is still 100% playable, it has offline modes for all maps and game modes with as many bots as your computer can handle. you just need to find the right .ini file and change the max settings for bots. its a faily simple process that i was surprised i couldn't find online, maybe wasn't looking in the right place. oh well.   anyways its a good game with a good offline mode! but be warned the online is pretty dead at this time of the review and also a BIG side note i downloaded the DLC but the GFWL wont install it for some reason... I have yet to be able to play my DLC i purchased which is irratating, but the game is still fully playable 8/10

It's entertaining, fun and enjoyable. Section 8: Prejudice is a sequel to Section 8 and honestly, not much is different. The graphics are a tad better and there is more features, but it still feels like the first game, which is not a bad thing. Both are very pleasant to play and provide a lot to do. Prejudice has a 5 hour single-player, which is pretty average now-a-days, but it's multiplayer provides many more hours of boisterous gameplay. You can make 7 classes for plenty styles of play, all matches last a long time, not just TDM or CTF and you can call in a lot of support items such as hover bikes, mech suits, and artillery. GFWL could provide some issues, but so far it has not been a problem for me. Overall Section 8: Prejudice is fun. Sort of generic, but that's not entirely a bad thing. You'll have fun with it.

I find that the use of brand new technology, such as the aspect of having to enter your product key every time, adds an important depth to the title and helps the player to build up an emotional attachment to Games for Windows Live. Speaking of GFWL, I find that the enforced use of it to play multiplayer is much improved over the reliable, easy to use and aesthetically pleasing existing interface of Steam really does improve my experience and definitely doesn't make me lose all motivation to even attempt to play the game. In addition to all the points I made above, I find that the use of the generic fps-set-in-the-future campaign really engages the player. 11/10 would bang.

Also there is no spawn timer because you spawn in orbit and crash down without a parachute to any point the map. And if you land on someone you instantly kill them. If you ever wanted to feel like Iron Man, this is the game to do it. WHY did it not sell well? WHY? It's so good :(  This is why we can't have nice things. Or maybe it was because it was on GFWL...

I was looking forwards to playing this game again after stopping for a year, completely forgotten why I didn't touch it, then it occured to me.  - Teammate AIs are dumb, all of the missions that involving killing you have to do by yourself. - All enemy AI know exactly where you are; even with maxed stealth, and will seek AND prioritise you first. - All AI know what events will occur and will move into position 30 seconds early to get the instant drop on it (obvious with the 'Vital Information Package' mission). - The Difficulty doesn't improve the strategy of the AI, instead it makes them up to 300% stronger (I had the jump on an enemy but he still destroyed me with the same shotgun I used on him, with one shot). Wouldn't surprise me if they scaled the health.  After playing for 3 hours I'm leaving this Review here to let myself know not to play this enfuriating game.

Lot of game for little money. This struck me as a shelf-worthy major title trying a new business angle. Well, it worked, and I have to say it's the best $4 I've ever spent on a game (4-pack for $15, rounded up). Lots of game modes, hotswappable AI bots that are refreshingly challenging and NOT functionally ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, and a general feeling of polish that made me all the more surprised to learn it was an XBLA title. This game isn't bursting with originality, but is at least built on tested, solid gameplay concepts.  Downpoints are GfWL's buggy, frustrating hooks in the multiplayer experience, and a campaign whose length makes a Modern Warfare game look like Oblivion.

A surprisingly good FPS game. The levels are modified player vs CPU levels, but it feels almost as good as a dedicated single player game. The shooting is solid. The level design is good. Some areas are somewhat challenging. And darn it, I had fun with this game. Definately worth checking out.

This is a pretty fun game, and it's on quite a good sale at the moment. The horde mode is pretty fun, but I'm not a fan of the competitive multiplayer. The single player is decently long, but never really above average.

Section 8: Prejudice is a very solid Sci-Fi shooter; in fact I haven't had this much fun with a PC based Sci-Fi power armor game since Shogo. Then again, there aren't many of them. But the systems are really nice, the AI is decent and does more than just have head on assaults, and your squaddies are actually a help. In addition, the weapons have a nice feel to them, the armor really feels like powered armor, and the orbital drops are just really cool. The ability to change your loadouts not just based on weapons, but on ammo and supporting tools is nice also. The storyline is solid, and the voice acting decent; it's a pleasant surprise to find a shooter with a decent single-player storyline these days. Definitely Recommended!
This is an epic game that I'd say combines Battlefront and Call of Duty in a mashup with a Halo feel. Great game for only $15!

Drop down into the battlefield! No more spawning and pre-defined positions, you choose where you want to be, you fly from the sky towards your objective, crashing down in the midst of war, gun firing all the while, shooting down enemy after enemy, and just as you sigh with relief to your teammates that the control point was succesfully taken over, you look into the sky and see shimmering streaks falling down, enemy reinforcements just arriving to take back their territory.  Section 8 is my favourite fps, it allows brilliant tactics, has graphics that aren't too shabby, and the gameplay is simply awesome! Furthermore, you can call in vehicles, supply drops, turrets, whatever you need in the midst of the battlefield to satisfy your needs! Hold your position, or bring hell to the enemy!
It's nice to see a large scale, teamwork oriented, objective based multi-player game in the midst of all the TDM focused console ports out there these days.

One of the best multiplayer experiences out there. It takes just one or two hours to get into the game (tip: play the solo campaign!) but then the deep and feature-rich gameplay is so extremely rewarding. Also, there are so many cool features such as jet packs, drop-ins from the sky, finishing moves, etc.  Highly recommended!

The graphics are nice, the sound is decent, the atmosphere perfect... considering the low price. Multiplayer is hectic and singleplayer will surprise you with all the different stuff you need to do. This game also requires a bit of thinking on how you should set up your weapons and armor, which objectives you are going for and so on.  All things considered, for 12 Euros, this game is a blast and highly recommended if you are looking for a futuristic shooter!

***SUPER-DISCLAIMER: ONLINE IS DEAD. AND NOT JUST NO-PLAYERS DEAD, SERVERS SHUT DOWN DEAD.***  Now that the elephant in the room has been addressed, this game is still pretty good. There's a five-hour campaign that's pretty enjoyable, and the robust multiplayer can still be played... with bots. There are multiple loadouts and classes to choose from, vehicles and turrets to deploy, and a variety of different game modes, where there are various secondary objectives like protecting a convoy or picking up wreckage strewn about the map to spice up the match. It also has jetpacks, tanks and mechs. Yay!  If you're thirsty for a sci-fi FPS and see this on sale for three bucks, go ahead and give it a shot.

I learned that this game was run by Windows LIVE, and since that has gone away, there is no way for me to create such a profile, i could care less about the multiplayer shutting down, but i would at least like to save my damn progress. or at the very least create some ♥♥♥♥ing classes for bot mode or something, this is ridiculous steam, you shouldve at least warned me before i spent 30 bucks on childhood nostalgia that is broken.
